input2:
y.o., recent medication changes including, Furosemide to Torsemide, presents with several weeks of weight gain of 15 lbs. Baseline weight around 200. Worsening orthopnea and DOE. Denies clear precipitants such as dietary indiscretion or med noncompliance or chest pain or palpitations however there is some concern that he has had some difficulty with following medication changes in the past few months. Seen in clinic today with Dr. reports that, he changed his HCTZ to spironolactone, increased his furosemide, then changed furosemide to torsemide (up to 40 mg) but pt kept putting on weight, edema worse, breathing worse, creatinine worse, enlarging abdomen with concern for missing med doses. Directly admitted from clinic. Patient denies current chest pain or SOB.  
On floor vital signs 97.5  140/50  56  20  95  RA Labs were remarkable for K 5.5, Cre 2.4, BNP ~6700
EKG: sinus brady, no sig peaked T waves, QRS 130 close to 
baseline of 114, PR 290 (baseline 294), TWI I AVL stable, Q in 
III (stable)
Interventions: given 40mg IV lasix.
ROS:  positive per HPI, otherwise negative

+ hypertension

+ s/p radiacal prostatectomy + radiation for prostate CA
+ h/o hyperkalemia
+ DM2

EXTREMITIES: pretibial edema 1+ up to knees

﻿
ECHO:
Portable TTE (Complete) Done at 9:09:28 AM      
FINAL Conclusions  
Left atrium is moderately dilated. Left ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There is mild regional 
left ventricular systolic dysfunction with basal inferior and inferolateral hypokinesis. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = 45-50%). The right ventricular cavity is mildly dilated with mild global free wall hypokinesis. The aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. The aortic arch is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is no pericardial effusion. 
﻿
IMPRESSION: Mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, c/w CAD. Mild ischemic mitral regurgitation. 
﻿
Compared with the prior study (images reviewed), regional LV systolic dysfunction is new. Finding discussed with Dr. at 1043 hours on the day of the study.   
﻿
Cardiovascular Report Stress Study Date 
IMPRESSION: No anginal symptoms or additional ST segment changes from baseline. Appropriate hemodynamic response to the Persantine infusion. 
Nuclear report sent separately. 
﻿
CARDIAC PERFUSION PHARM Study Date
IMPRESSION:  
1.  No reversible perfusion defect. 
2.  Severe fixed basal and mid inferior wall defect.  Mild fixed inferolateral wall defect. 
3.  Inferior and septal wall hypokinesis. 
4.  LVEF 36% and moderate LV enlargement.
﻿
CHEST (PORTABLE AP) Study Date  7:15 AM 
Severe cardiomegaly is stable. Mild pulmonary edema is 
minimally increased.  The left hemidiaphragm is mildly elevated.  There are bibasilar atelectasis and small bilateral effusions.
